title: Opening Research Information by Law?
content: For over two decades, the open access movement has advocated for—and delivered on—the goal of making the published results of… Read More The post Opening Research Information by Law? appeared first on Knowledge Rights 21 .
creator: Herman Rucic
sourceDescription: KR21 (Knowledge Rights 21) works to bring about changes in legislation and practice across Europe that will strengthen the right of all to access and apply knowledge for the benefit of research, science and society at large. This – and the education, knowledge valorisation and cultural participation it enables – are essential for innovation and development, and must be available to everyone in the information society, free of unnecessary hindrance or limitation. To achieve this, we believe that we need a modern legislative framework that places current research, education and scientific practice front and centre.

title: The Internet, Switched Off
content: When Iranians revolted, their government cut them off from the world. Mobile networks degraded first. Fixed-line disruptions followed. Instead of cutting cables, the authorities interfered with routing and key protocols. As Iran shut down the Internet, Revolutionary Guards crushed the protests, killing thousands. It’s not an isolated story. Internet shutdowns are rising fast. In 2016, digital rights groups  documented  some 75 shutdowns. By 2024, that figure ha...
creator: Anda Bologa

title: Vangittujen toimittajien terveys heikossa tilassa
content: Dear President, I am writing to you regarding the 12 journalists, from or associated with Meydan TV, who are currently on trial in Azerbaijan, arbitrarily detained since December 2024. The criminal proceedings against them are politically motivated and are part of the government’s ongoing crackdown on independent media. title: Open science practices in different disciplines (4) - An interview with Prof Panos Merkouris and Prof Lorenzo Squintani, Faculty of Law | Open Access | Library | University of Groningen
content: "Open science in Law is as important as it is in other disciplines. Of course, Law has some peculiarities, in the sense that our primary data (laws and judgments) are usually already publicly available. Open science can, however, certainly be beneficial for empirical law research, which uses interviews or questionnaires. It can provide more transparency and facilitates checking the quality of the work and reusing the materials for further research."

title: Met Office: A review of the UK’s climate in 2025
content: The UK’s climate saw a record-breaking 2025, with the year being both the warmest and sunniest seen since observations began. The year 2025 has joined 2024, 2023, 2022 and 2014 in the UK’s top-five warmest years. In this review, we take a look back at the UK’s climate in 2025 and place the record-breaking year in the context of human-caused climate change. title: Rethinking Troy: how years of careful peace, not epic war, shaped this bronze age city
content: Imagine a city that thrived for thousands of years, its streets alive with workshops, markets and the laughter of children, yet that is remembered for a single night of fire. That city is Troy. Long before Homer’s epics immortalised its fall, Troy was a place of everyday life. Potters shaped jars and bowls destined to travel far beyond the settlement itself, moving through wide horizons of exchange and connection. Bronze tools rang in busy workshops. content: Marcus Bösch , the editor of the Understanding TikTok newsletter , has put together a checklist for “when a meme is everywhere and you’re unsure whether to cover it, contextualise it, or leave it alone.” ( PDF version here ). The checklist — M.A.T.T.E.R. — covers six things to consider: Meaning, ‘Affect’ (emotion), Type of format, Temporality, Ethics and relevance. title: Italy: Cutro shipwreck trial begins after another deadly week in the Mediterranean
content: Amnesty International representatives will be present at the trial and spokespeople are available on request. On 30 January, six Italian coastguard and custom officials will go on trial for failing to launch rescue operations which could have prevented a shipwreck that killed more than 90 people near the town of Cutro in southern Italy in February 2023. At least 94 people, including 34 children, drowned in Italian territorial waters near Steccato di Cutro, Calabria, as the “Summer Love” vessel s...

title: Climate change and La Niña made ‘devastating’ southern African floods more intense
content: “Exceptionally heavy” rainfall that led to deadly flooding across southern Africa in recent weeks was made more intense by a combination of climate change and La Niña. This is according to a rapid attribution study by the World Weather Attribution service. From late December 2025 to early January, south-eastern Africa was hit hard by intense downpours that resulted in more than a year’s worth of rain falling in some areas in just a few days, according to the study. This led to severe flooding th...

content: Slow Down First. That’s How Newsrooms Move Faster With AI. Most newsrooms assume they need an army of engineers or a big tech budget to experiment with AI. They don't. What they need is a repeatable process, the right collaborators and time to understand their problems before reaching for tools, AI or otherwise. title: What Counts As A Mind?
content: Last summer, OpenAI released GPT-5, a ChatGPT update that was intended to improve the user experience by “ minimizing sycophancy ,” among other upgrades. But for a subset of users who had been treating the chatbot as a romantic partner, the change was devastating: Their relationships were severed overnight. Conversation logs were deleted with the update, in some cases erasing weeks or months of flirtatious, personal and intimate messages, and the chatbot’s tone abruptly changed. People’s formerl...

title: French diplomats are taking on MAGA — one meme at a time
content: PARIS — When a French government account publicly sparred with the White House over Greenland on X, it wasn’t a mistake or the work of some rogue diplomat. It was part of a deliberate new strategy by Paris to fight online disinformation from Russia, China and, increasingly, MAGA-aligned voices in the United States. sourceDescription: KR21 (Knowledge Rights 21) works to bring about changes in legislation and practice across Europe that will strengthen the right of all to access and apply knowledge for the benefit of research, science and society at large. This – and the education, knowledge valorisation and cultural participation it enables – are essential for innovation and development, and must be available to everyone in the information society, free of unnecessary hindrance or limitation. To achieve this, we believe that we need a modern legislative framework that places current research, education and scientific practice front and centre.
